clinical_study.brief_title: Effectiveness of Higher Aspirin Dosing for Prevention of Preeclampsia in High Risk Obese Gravida
clinical_study.official_title: Effectiveness of Higher Aspirin Dosing for Prevention of Preeclampsia in High Risk Obese Gravida: An Open Label, Comparative Effectiveness, Randomized Controlled Trial (ASPREO Trial)

lead_sponsor.agency: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

clinical_study.source: The University of Texas Health Science Center, Houston

brief_summary.textblock: To compare the incidence of preeclampsia in obese pregnant women (BMI greater than 30) with a singleton gestation at less than 20 weeks and either a history of preeclampsia in a prior pregnancy or stage I hypertension or pre-gestational diabetes who are randomized to either 81mg/day aspirin or 162mg/day aspirin.

primary_outcome.description: based on American College Obstetrics and Gynecology (ACOG) guidelines

secondary_outcome.description: development of hypertension anytime during pregnancy based on ACOG guidelines
Placental abruption occurs when the placenta separates from the inner wall of the uterus before birth. As assessed by treating OBGYN
onset of seizures (convulsions) in a woman with pre-eclampsia per ACOG guidelines

group of symptoms that occur in pregnant women who have: hemolysis(H): (the breakdown of red blood cells)elevated liver enzymes (EL). low platelet (LP) count. Assessed by ACOG guidelines and measured in urine and blood samples
excessive bleeding following the birth of a baby

secondary_outcome.time_frame: during labor to 24 hrs post delivery
secondary_outcome.description: any other bleeding associated with birth not otherwise categorized

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Outcomes- Gestational age at delivery

secondary_outcome.description: A method to quickly summarize the health of newborn children against infant mortality Appearance, Pulse, Grimace, Activity, and Respiration. Scored from 0-10

secondary_outcome.measure: Neonatal Outcomes-Neonatal Intensive Care Unit (NICU) length of stay
secondary_outcome.time_frame: from birth until discharge from NICU (about 1 to 10 weeks)
from birth until discharge from NICU (about 1 to 10 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: bleeding inside or around the ventricles in the brain.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from birth until discharge from NICU (about 1 to 10 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: chronic lung disease that affects newborns (mostly premature) and infants.

secondary_outcome.time_frame: from birth until discharge from NICU (about 1 to 10 weeks)
secondary_outcome.description: medical condition where a portion of the bowel dies

intervention.description: Low dose aspirin was initially reported as having a beneficial effect at preeclampsia
Low dose aspirin was initially reported as having a beneficial effect at preeclampsia

criteria.textblock:
Inclusion Criteria
- A singleton gestation at less than 20 weeks at time of enrollment, with a BMI greater than or equal to 30 and one of the following:
1. History of preeclampsia in a prior pregnancy
- Diagnosis will be obtained by review of records, and if unavailable then patient history. Preeclampsia diagnosis may be made in antepartum or postpartum period.
OR 2. At least stage I hypertension during pregnancy
- Stage I hypertension is defined as a systolic blood pressure between 130- 139 mm Hg or diastolic blood pressure between 80-89 mm Hg21
- This blood pressure criteria is met regardless of medication usage
- The patient must have a blood pressure reading ≥ 130-139/80-89 mm Hg at least during 1 clinic visit during the current pregnancy; before or at time of enrollment
OR
3. Pre-gestational diabetes
- Type 1 and Type 2 diabetics are included
- Gestational diabetes mellitus diagnosed prior to 20 weeks gestational age will also be included
Exclusion Criteria
- Known allergy/prior adverse reaction/any medical condition where aspirin is contraindicated
- Already on aspirin prior to pregnancy
- Baseline renal Disease
- Baseline proteinuria identified at time of enrollment, defined as urine analysis with 3+ protein, or urine protein to creatinine ratio ≥ 0.3
- Systemic Lupus Erythematosus
- Seizure disorder on medications
- HIV positive status
- Known major fetal anomalies
- Multifetal gestation
